titlestmt.title: The Vision of Queen Katharine, 1807 : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 20KB; 2 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 92KB to 1100KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; UNC LibrariesMarch 2020
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a digital edition of Blake’s water color illustrations to the plays of William Shakespeare.
Although less extensive and well known than his illustrations of John Milton’s poems, Blake’s water colors based on Shakespeare’s plays constitute a significant group of designs. The earliest, dating from c. 1779, is probably one of Blake’s illustrations of English history but nonetheless evokes Shakespeare’s King Lear. The series of seven small ovals picturing characters from the plays also dates from Blake’s early years. The concentrated focus on just one or two figures filling most of the pictorial space may be Blake’s response to popular interest in miniature portraiture. The reason for his execution of this group is not known; like the English history designs, they may have been intended for eventual publication as engravings. The series of Shakespeare character portraits by John Hamilton Mortimer, published as engravings in the mid-1770s, may have influenced Blake’s similar project.
Oberon, Titania and Puck with Fairies Dancing is one of Blake’s largest water colors of the 1780s. Its size and quality suggest that it may have been intended for exhibition, like the water colors illustrating the life of Joseph displayed at the Royal Academy in 1785. The circle of dancers and Puck’s stance with arms raised echo similar motifs in George Romney’s Leveson-Gower Family, painted in 1776-77 and published as a mezzotint by John Raphael Smith in 1781.
Blake was clearly attracted to the vision of Queen Katherine in Henry VIII, act 4, scene 2, for he executed four versions beginning c. 1783-90 and concluding with the highly finished and complex water color of c. 1825-26. Blake’s water color of Queen Katherine’s dream dated 1809 is part of a series of six illustrations to Shakespeare’s plays commissioned by Joseph Thomas, the clergyman who had earlier employed Blake to illustrate Milton’s Comus and Paradise Lost. In a letter of 31 July 1801 to William Hayley, John Flaxman added a postscript to Blake, including the following: “he [Thomas] also desired you [Blake] will make two designs in bister or Indian Ink, from Shakespeare’s Troylus & Cressida, Coriolanus, either of the 3 plays of Henry 6.th Richard the 3.d or Henry the 8.th each design for one play for which he will give a Guinea each, the dimensions as follow the paper. an upright square of 12 Inches & half by 8 Inches, within this Space leaving a moderate margin, the principal figure not exceeding 6 Inches high” (Butlin 547). Blake’s designs (most now trimmed) roughly follow these size requirements, necessitated by Thomas’s desire to create an extra-illustrated copy of the 1632 second folio of Shakespeare’s plays, but Blake waited eight years before completing the commission, changed the medium from monochrome drawings to water colors, and illustrated only two plays, Richard III and Henry VIII, specified by Flaxman. Blake may have chosen the other passages for illustration, at some point convincing Thomas of their appropriateness.
Many of Blake’s Shakespeare designs show his predilection for scenes dealing with perceptions that extend beyond the world of the physical senses. The four versions of Queen Katherine’s dream epitomize this lifelong interest in imaginative and visionary experiences. A corollary is Blake’s attraction to representations of the arts, demonstrated by Oberon, Titania and Puck with Fairies Dancing and his portrayal of Pegasus, the classical embodiment of poetic inspiration, in As If an Angel Dropped Down from the Clouds among the designs for Thomas.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.
Morris Eaves, Robert N. Essick, and Joseph Viscomi, editors
Joseph Fletcher, managing editor, Michael Fox, assistant editor
The William Blake Archive

objdescid.compdate: 1807The date is inscribed on the work lower left; see the Textual Transcription.

objinfo.medium: pen and ink and water color over pencilThe inscription, lower left, is in pen and ink.

provenance.name: Fitzwilliam Museum
provenance.note: Thomas Butts; by inheritance to Thomas Butts, Jr., in 1845; sold Sotheby's, 26 March 1852, lot 166 (£9 to Charles Wentworth Dilke); his son, Charles Wentworth Dilke, 2nd, by inheritance in 1869; sold Christie's, 10 April 1911, lot 127 (£52.10s. to Sidney Cockerell acting for the Friends of the Fitzwilliam Museum); accessioned by the Fitzwilliam Museum in 1911.

desc.objtitle: The Vision of Queen Katharine, Object 1 (Butlin 548)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three large figures, two female and one male, and at least twenty-five smaller figures occupy the space of the composition, which represents The Vision of Queen Katharine in Act 4, Scene 2 of Shakespeare's play Henry VIII. The central female figure of Queen Katharine reclines on a bed or couch with legs together at left but with her torso raised and facing forward. She has long hair and wears a gown and veil along with a crown. Both arms are bent and raised just above the horizontal with palms facing up. Her head and eyes are also raised, perhaps to better see the visionary activity above her. Queen Katharine is the wife of King Henry VIII who wishes to divorce her (as she has not born a male heir) and marry Anne Boleyn. Katharine becomes ill, and it is during her sickness in which The Vision occurs. The bed or couch on which she sits has arms on both sides and is covered in what appears to be a patterned fabric decorated with Gothic arches and other motifs. A pillow is visible at right and drapery or sheets cover the seat and closest edge of the piece of furniture. In front of the bed in both lower corners of the composition, the other two large figures sit facing each other on straight-backed chairs. Both have their eyes closed and appear to sleep with their heads supported on one bent arm. The figure in the right corner is a gowned female with long, curly hair who rests her elbow on a soft object of some sort (perhaps a pillow?) on the table at her right. This is probably Patience, a servant to the queen. The male figure at left has white hair and a long beard; he is also gowned. This is probably Griffith, the queen's usher. He rests his elbow on a similar table behind him and turns his head to face forward. In his right hand, which is by his side, he holds a scroll and pen or quill. The floor between these two figures is decorated with hexagons and quatrefoils. The twenty-five other smaller figures in the scene fly around the seated figure of Queen Katharine in serpentine formations. Seven of these figures form a semi-circle around the right side of Queen Katharine's body in the lower half of the image. They fly atop a plume of wispy clouds. Just above the center of the lower margin, the lowest of these figures faces right and appears to stand on tiptoe on the floor. She is gowned and female with short (or perhaps coiffed) hair and a crown. Her left leg is bent and her right is extended backward. With her right hand, she holds (and perhaps plays) a lyre and with her left arm, which is extended, she holds the hand of the figure above her at right, who flies upward and faces away and to the right. This figure is also a gowned female who holds a trumpet or horn in her raised right hand. Above and to the right of this figure, a third crowned and gowned female figure flies facing forward and slightly right as an infant or putto flies beside her at left facing away. The female figure plays a harp with both hands. Above and to the left of this pair, a second pair of figures flies upward and to the left. Both figures appear young, perhaps children. The lower figure at right, whose gender is indeterminate, raises one arm upward; the higher figure, who faces forward, has long hair and is likely female. Immediately to the left of this figure, the seventh figure in this group, who has coiffed hair, a crown, and a gown, faces away but bends to the left with arms extended and spread. In her raised right hand, she holds a serpentine object (perhaps a horn or shell?) and with her lowered left, the right side of a laurel crown. Together with another figure at left who holds the other side of the crown, she may be preparing to crown Queen Katharine below. This moment is referenced directly in the play's text: "the first two [Personages] hold a spare garland over her head" (Act 4, Scene 2). A second group of small figures above and to the left of Queen Katharine forms a complete circle of eight figures who fly atop a circle of clouds. The first of these figures near the lower right portion of the circle flies right and extends her left arm to hold the other side of the laurel crown over the head of Queen Katharine. In her right hand, she holds and perhaps plays a lyre. She wears a crown and a gown and her long hair streams behind her at left. Directly below her right arm, a small nude infant or putto faces away and flies up and to the right. Directly above this pair at right, two small figures who wear gowns and face forward and left fly upward with arms raised overhead. A fifth figure flies to the left directly above this pair, and she wears a long gown and extends her left arm to hold a lyre and perhaps touch the right arm of the figure flying at her left whose body is also horizontally and turns to look back toward her companion. She also wears a gown, crown, and has long hair. Below the extended left arm of this figure, a seventh figure whose body is twisted faces and flies downward. With both arms bent and raised, she plays two trumpets or horns. Directly below this figure, the final figure in this circle flies to the right with her left arm raised horizontally and her right extended upward near the above figure. She wears a gown and has long hair. She holds round object, possibly flowers. Above the two figures holding the laurel crown above Queen Katharine, a vertical line of three figures fly upward. The two lower figures face forward and turn their head to look up. The closer figure holds a harp, which she appears to play with her left hand, and the further figure turns her head slightly to the right. A third figure above this pair faces forward and leans to the left. She wears a gown and has long hair. In her right arm she holds a lute; she raised her left arm vertically, palm facing up and forward. Directly above this figure two gowned figures who face away and lean to the left wear gowns and fly upward. Both extend their arms vertically and hold (and play) large tambourines. Between the heads of this pair, the left leg and foot of an otherwise unseen figure is visible against the upper margin. A final group of five figures forms a circle in the upper left portion of the composition. Directly below and left of the lowest tambourine player at top, a gowned female figure flies to the left with her body horizontal and arms extended horizontally. She wears a crown above her long hair. In her left hand she holds a lyre and with her right, she appears to reach for two round objects (possibly flowers, like those associated with figures below) in the encircling clouds. Forming the left side of the circle, a gowned female figure flies upside down with her body twisted to the right. Both of her arms are raised overhead to hold or take flowers or fruit(?) from the basket carried on the head of the gowned female figure to her right who also flies to the right and wears a gown. This figure holds her basket with both arms bent overhead. To her right, the fourth figure flies right, facing away, with arms extended horizontally. She too appears to hold small objects, perhaps fruit or flowers, in both hands. Below her right arm, the final figure in the scene, a small infant or putto, flies up while facing away with arms extended. Two piers or pillars against the margins support (what is likely) a pointed Gothic arch partially visible in the background of the upper half of the scene.

component.illusobjdesc: Three large figures and at least twenty-five smaller figures occupy the space of the composition, which represents The Vision of Queen Katharine in Act 4, Scene 2 of Shakespeare's play Henry VIII. The central female figure of Queen Katharine reclines or sits on a bed or couch with legs together (and right leg bent) at left but with her torso raised and facing forward. She has long hair and wears a gown and veil along with a crown. Both arms are bent and raised just above the horizontal with palms facing up. Her head and eyes are also raised, perhaps to better see the visionary activity above her. Her mouth is slightly open. Queen Katharine is the wife of King Henry VIII who wishes to divorce her (as she has not born a male heir) and marry Anne Boleyn. Katharine becomes ill, and it is during her sickness in which The Vision occurs.

The bed or couch on which Queen Katharine, the central figure, sits large arms on either side. Its fabric is patterned with Gothic arches that resemble the arch in the upper part of the scene. The arches above the queen's legs form niches containing the outlines of standing human figures, facing forward. Scroll-like patterns are above these niches. A pillow is visible at right and drapery or sheets cover the seat and fall over the front edge of the furniture.
The arches above the queen's legs on the decorated cloth covering her couch form niches containing pictures of standing human figures, facing forward.

Three large figures and at least twenty-five smaller figures occupy the space of this composition, which represents The Vision of Queen Katharine in Shakespeare's play Henry VIII. In front of the bed in both lower corners, the other two large figures sit facing each other on straight-backed chairs. Both have their eyes closed and appear to sleep with their heads supported on one bent arm. The figure in the right corner is a gowned female with long, curly hair who rests her right elbow on a soft object of some sort (perhaps a pillow?) on the table at her right and leans her head on her hand. This is probably Patience, a servant to the queen. Her left arm is at her side with her left hand resting in her lap near her knee. Her legs are bent, and her left foot is visible beneath her gown.

In the lower right corner, a gowned female figure sits in a straight-backed chair facing left and rests her right elbow on a soft object of some sort (perhaps a pillow?) on a table at her right. The back of the chair includes Gothic arches.

Three large figures and at least twenty-five smaller figures occupy the space of this composition, which represents The Vision of Queen Katharine in Shakespeare's play Henry VIII. In front of the bed in both lower corners, the other two large figures sit facing each other on straight-backed chairs. Both have their eyes closed and appear to sleep with their heads supported on one bent arm. The male figure at left has white hair and a long beard; he is also gowned. This is probably Griffith, the queen's usher. He rests his elbow on a table behind him and rests his head on his left hand with his head turned to face forward. In his right hand, which is by his side, he holds a scroll and pen or quill. Both legs are bent, and his right is extended with his shoe-clad foot visible beneath his gown.

In the lower left corner, a gowned male figure sits in a straight-backed chair facing right and rests his right elbow on a table at his left. In his right hand he holds a scroll and a quill or pen by his side. The back of the chair includes Gothic arches.
The (stone or marble?) floor between the two large figures in the bottom half of the composition is decorated with hexagons and quatrefoils.

Twenty-five smaller figures fly or hover around the seated figure of Queen Katharine in serpentine formations. Seven of these figures form a semi-circle around the right side of Queen Katharine's body in the lower half of the image and fly atop a plume of wispy clouds. Just above the center of the lower margin, the first figure faces right and appears to stand on tiptoe on the floor. She is gowned and female with short (or perhaps coiffed) hair and a crown. Her left leg is bent and her right is extended backward. With her right hand, she holds (and perhaps plays) a harp or lyre and with her left arm, which is extended, she holds the hand of the figure above her at right toward whom she may also look with her head up.

Twenty-five smaller figures fly or hover around the seated figure of Queen Katharine in serpentine formations. Seven of these figures form a semi-circle around the right side of Queen Katharine's body in the lower half of the image and fly atop a plume of wispy clouds. The second figure right of center flies upward and to the right with her legs together and extended backward. She has hair coiffed in a bun and wears a gown. Her right arm is raised at 135 degrees and holds a horn or trumpet; her left is at her side and with her left hand holds the hand of the figure below her. She faces away but turns her head up and to the right.

Twenty-five smaller figures fly or hover around the seated figure of Queen Katharine in serpentine formations. Seven of these figures form a semi-circle around the right side of Queen Katharine's body in the lower half of the image and fly atop a plume of wispy clouds. Directly right of Queen Katharine's left hand, a third gowned female figure flies facing forward and slightly left as an infant or putto flies beside her at left. The female figure wears a crown (perhaps of laurels?) and plays a harp with both hands. Her legs are together with knees slightly bent.

Twenty-five smaller figures fly or hover around the seated figure of Queen Katharine in serpentine formations. Seven of these figures form a semi-circle around the right side of Queen Katharine's body in the lower half of the image and fly atop a plume of wispy clouds. Directly right of Queen Katharine's left hand, a third gowned female figure flies facing forward and slightly left as a nude infant or putto flies beside her at left. The child faces away but turns to look right and up, likely toward the female figure at right. Its hair is short, its leg are bent, and both arms are raised vertically.

Twenty-five smaller figures fly or hover around the seated figure of Queen Katharine in serpentine formations. Seven of these figures form a semi-circle around the right side of Queen Katharine's body in the lower half of the image and fly atop a plume of wispy clouds. Above the harp-playing figure near the right margin, a pair of small figures fly up and to the left. The rightmost of these appears to have small hair and wear a gown. The figure raises one arm vertically to touch the shoulder of its companion at left

Twenty-five smaller figures fly or hover around the seated figure of Queen Katharine in serpentine formations. Seven of these figures form a semi-circle around the right side of Queen Katharine's body in the lower half of the image and fly atop a plume of wispy clouds. Above the harp-playing figure near the right margin, a pair of small figures fly up and to the left. The child at left faces forward but turns her head to look right. She has long hair and wears a gown. Her right arm is extended vertically and her left is at her side, touching or holding the arm of the figure at her right. Her legs are extended and together.

Twenty-five smaller figures fly or hover around the seated figure of Queen Katharine in serpentine formations. Seven of these figures form a semi-circle around the right side of Queen Katharine's body in the lower half of the image and fly atop a plume of wispy clouds. The seventh figure in this group flies or hovers above and slightly right of Queen Katharine's head. She has coiffed hair, a crown, and a gown, and she faces away but bends to the left with arms extended and spread. In her raised right hand, she holds a serpentine object (perhaps a horn or shell?) and with her lowered left, the right side of a laurel crown. Together with another figure at left who holds the other side of the crown, she may be preparing to crown Queen Katharine below. This moment is referenced directly in the play's text: "the first two [Personages] hold a spare garland over her head" (Act 4, Scene 2).

The seven smaller figures who form a semi-circle around the right side of Queen Katharine's body hold and/or play a variety of objects and instruments. The lowest figure holds a lyre in her right hand. The figure above her at right holds a trumpet or horn, and the rightmost figure above her holds and plays a harp. The highest figure in this group holds a serpentine object (perhaps a horn or shell?) in her raised right hand and a laurel crown in her lowered left hand.

The seven small figures who form a semi-circle around the right side of Queen Katharine's body fly atop a single plume of clouds that appears to rise from the ground below the lowest figure or, alternatively, originate with this figure herself.

A second group of small figures above and to the left of Queen Katharine forms a complete circle of eight figures who fly atop a circle of clouds. The first of these figures near the lower right portion of the circle flies right and extends her left arm to hold the other side of the laurel crown over the head of Queen Katharine. This moment is referenced directly in the play's text: "the first two [Personages] hold a spare garland over her head" (Act 4, Scene 2). In the figure's right hand, she holds and perhaps plays a harp or lyre. She wears a crown and a gown and her long hair streams behind her at left. Her right leg is bent and extended backward.

A second group of small figures above and to the left of Queen Katharine forms a complete circle of eight figures who fly atop a circle of clouds. Directly below the right arm of the first figure, a small nude infant or putto faces away and flies up and to the right. He has short, curly hair and extends both arms vertically. His legs are bent and extended backward.

A second group of small figures above and to the left of Queen Katharine forms a complete circle of eight figures who fly atop a circle of clouds. Directly above the first female figure holding the laurel crown, two small figures with short hair who wear gowns fly upward with arms raised overhead, hands together, and at least one leg extended. The leftmost faces forward with an open mouth.

A second group of small figures above and to the left of Queen Katharine forms a complete circle of eight figures who fly atop a circle of clouds. Directly above the first female figure holding the laurel crown, two small figures with short hair who wear gowns fly upward with arms raised overhead, hands together, and at least one leg extended. The figure at right twists to look left and bends his left leg.

A second group of small figures above and to the left of Queen Katharine forms a complete circle of eight figures who fly atop a circle of clouds. The fifth figure with long hair flies to the left directly above the pair of children, and she wears a long gown and extends her left arm to hold a lyre or harp and perhaps touch the right arm of the figure flying at her left toward whom she may also look.

A second group of small figures above and to the left of Queen Katharine forms a complete circle of eight figures who fly atop a circle of clouds. The sixth figure, at the top center of the circle, flies left with her body horizontal but turns her head to look right, back toward her companion at right. She wears a crown over her long hair and a long gown. Both arms are extended horizontally; with her right arm she touches or perhaps plays a harp or lyre held by the figure at her right and with her left arm she appears to reach for small circular objects that may be flower blossoms(?). Her legs are together and extended to the right.

A second group of small figures above and to the left of Queen Katharine forms a complete circle of eight figures who fly atop a circle of clouds. Forming the left upper curve of the circle, the seventh figure, who is upside down, flies or hovers facing down with her body bent to the right. Although her head is up, the rest of her body is seen from behind. She has short hair and wears a gown. With both arms bent and raised, she holds two horns or trumpets, which she plays. Her legs are together and extended upward and to the right. The clouds to the left of his figure looks fiery.

A second group of small figures above and to the left of Queen Katharine forms a complete circle of eight figures who fly atop a circle of clouds. The final figure flies or hovers to form the lower left bend of the circle, where she flies to the right but faces forward. Her long hair is styled in a ponytail, and she wears a gown. Her left arm is raised horizontally in front of her, where she appears to reach for three circular objects, perhaps blossoms(?). Her right arm is raised vertically, and she holds two of the same round objects in her right hand, which is directly beside the elbow of the figure above her. Her legs are together and extended up and behind her.

The eight smaller figures who form a complete circle above and to the left of Queen Katharine hold and/or play a variety of objects and instruments. The lowest figure at right holds a lyre in her right hand and, in her left hand, a laurel crown, also held by the figure at her right. The fourth figure near the upper right bend in the circle holds a lyre, while the seventh figure on the upper left side holds and plays two horns or trumpets.

Two of the eight smaller figures who form a complete circle above and to the left of Queen Katharine may hold and/or reach for small circular objects that resemble flower blossoms. The top central figure may reach for them with her extended right arm, and the figure lower left may reach for these with her left arm and hold two blossoms in her right hand.

The eight smaller figures who form a complete circle above and to the left of Queen Katharine fly atop a ring of clouds that connects with the larger plume of clouds on the right side of the picture. The area of clouds left of the leftmost figure in the circle appears to be fiery.

Directly above the two figures holding the laurel crown above Queen Katharine, a vertical line of three figures fly upward. The two lower figures, who are very close together, face forward and turn their heads up. The closer figure, who wears a gown and may have long hair, holds a harp or lyre, which she appears to play with her left hand. She turns her head to look left.

Directly above the two figures holding the laurel crown above Queen Katharine, a vertical line of three figures fly upward. The two lower figures, who are very close together, face forward and turn their heads up. The figure further away in the pair may have long hair and may wear a gown.

Directly above the two figures holding the laurel crown above Queen Katharine, a vertical line of three figures fly upward. The third figure and highest figure in this trio faces forward and leans to the left. She wears a gown and has long hair. In her right arm she holds a lute, which she may play. She raises her left arm at 135 degrees, palm facing up and forward. She turns her head to look slightly left and her mouth may be open. Her legs are extended downward and together.

Two figures in the vertical trio of figures flying or hovering between and to the right of the two circular groups of figures hold instruments. The lowest and closest figure holds a harp that she appears to play with her left hand and the highest figure holds a lute in her bent left arm.
The vertical line of three figures who fly upward near the right side of the composition fly atop clouds that extend from the larger plume of clouds originating in the lower center of the picture.

Just below the upper margin of the design on the right, two gowned figures with long hair who face away and bend left wear gowns and fly upward or hover. Both extend their arms vertically and hold (and play) large tambourines. The rightmost figure appears to bend her right leg; both legs are extended backward. A cloud is visible beneath her.

A cloud is visible beneath the figure flying or hovering closest to the top right corner of the composition. This cloud connects with the larger plume of clouds extending upward from the lower center of the picture.

Just below the upper margin of the design on the right, two gowned figures with long hair who face away and bend left wear gowns and fly upward or hover. Both extend their arms vertically and hold (and play) large tambourines. The figure at left turns to head to face left and points left with her right hand. Her legs are together and extended below her.

Between the heads of the two figures just below the upper margin who fly upward is a single leg and foot extending from the margin that likely signifies the presence of another figure above these two that echoes their left-leaning posture.

A final group of five smaller figures forms a circle in the upper left portion of the composition. Directly below and left of the lowest tambourine player at top, a female figure flies to the left or hovers facing forward with her body horizontal and arms extended horizontally. She wears a crown above her long hair and a gown that exposes her breasts. In her left hand she holds a lyre, which she may play, and with her right, she appears to reach with fingers spread for two round objects (perhaps flower blossoms?) in the encircling clouds. She turns her head to look left and her mouth is open. Her left leg is extended backward.

A final group of five smaller figures forms a circle in the upper left portion of the composition. Forming the left side of the circle, the second female figure flies or hovers upside down but facing forward with her body bent to the right. She has long hair worn in a ponytail and wears a gown but with breasts exposed. Both of her arms are bent and raised overhead to hold or take fruits or blossoms(?) from the basket carried on the head of the figure to her right.

A final group of five smaller figures forms a circle in the upper left portion of the composition. The third figure who flies right or hovers at the bottom edge of the circle holds a basket full of fruit or flowers(?) atop her head with both arms bent upward. She faces forward but turns her head slightly left, perhaps to look toward the figure flying to her left. She has short hair and wears a gown that exposes her breasts. Her body is horizontal and her legs are together and extended backward.

A final group of five smaller figures forms a circle in the upper left portion of the composition. The fourth figure flies right or hovers near the lower right bend in the circle and faces away. She has long hair and wears a gown. Her arms are raised horizontally, and in each hand she appears to hold circular objects, perhaps fruit or blossoms(?) from the basket of the figure at her left. Her body is horizontal, though her torso is bent up and left. She extends her legs, which are together, to the left.

A final group of five smaller figures forms a circle in the upper left portion of the composition. Below the right arm of the fourth figure, the final figure in the scene, a small nude infant or putto, flies right or hovers while facing away with arms raised horizontally, perhaps holding a circular object (perhaps a fruit or blossom(?) similar to those held by other members of the group) in its right hand. The figure has short hair and turns its head left, perhaps to look toward the female figure at left. Its right leg is bent back at the knee, but both legs are extended backward.

Two of the five smaller figures who form a circle in the upper left portion of the composition carry or hold objects: the highest figure holds, and likely plays, a harp or lyre with her left hand, and the third figure in the lower left bend of the circle holds a (wicker?) basket on top of her head.

Four of the five smaller figures who form a circle in the upper left portion of the composition appear to hold or reach for small circular objects that may be fruits or flower blossoms from the fourth figure's basket: the top figure reaches for two blossoms with her extended right hand; the second, upside-down figure reaches or holds these with both hands; the third figure holds the basket containing most of these fruits or blossoms; the fourth figure holds one object in each of her extended arms; and the last figure, an infant or putto, may hold one such object in his horizontally raised right hand. Three of the flowers in the basket may be lilies.

The final group of five smaller figures who form a circle in the upper left portion of the composition fly or hover atop a ring of clouds that connects with the larger plume of clouds on the right side of the picture.

Two piers or pillars against the margins support (what is likely) a pointed, Gothic arch partially visible in the background of the upper half of the scene. The two capitals are decorated but not in a specific architectural order.
